height =   .........  m
Fig. 1.1 shows a plant pot falling from an upstairs balcony. The plant pot has a constant acceleration as it falls
A food scientist needs to find the average diameter of a pea
She places 14 peas against a ruler, as shown in Fig. 2.2
Use information from Fig. 2.2 to determine the average diameter of **one** pea
The food scientist needs to find the average density of some peas
She uses the following values:
mass of \(\text{peas} = 183 \text{g}\)
volume of \(\text{peas} = 250 \text{cm}^3\)
Calculate the average density of these peas
average density =   .........  \(g / \text{cm}^3\)
A different variety of pea has a density of \(0.89 \text{g} / \text{cm}^3\). One pea of this variety is placed in salt water. The density of the salt water is \(1.02 \text{g} / \text{cm}^3\)
State whether this pea floats or sinks in the salt water. Give a reason for your answer
answer
reason
Fig. 2.1 shows a pea plant. One of the pods is open, showing the peas inside
Calculate the resultant force acting on the skateboarder
resultant force =   .........  N
direction =
Describe the effect of the resultant force in (a) on the motion of the skateboarder
The skateboarder is moving along a horizontal path
The backward force is 100 N. The forward force is 100 N
Describe the motion of the skateboarder
Fig. 3.1 shows the horizontal forces acting on a skateboarder
State the principle of conservation of energy
Fig. 4.1 shows a type of light bulb. Energy changes occur when electrical energy is supplied to the light bulb, as shown in Fig. 4.1
total input = 500 J of electrical energy
Calculate the wasted energy when the total input energy is 500 J
Use information from Fig. 4.1
wasted energy =   .........  J
Describe the effect of the wasted energy on the air surrounding the light bulb
Table 4.1 lists situations in which energy is stored
Complete Table 4.1 by naming the form of energy stored in each situation

table.html:
situationform of energy stored
battery in a mobile phone
coal in the ground
a rotating turbine
water stored behind a hydroelectric dam

content.text: Using Fig. 5.2, determine the change in temperature for block A from 0 to 2 min
Determine the final temperature of block A
final temperature =   .........  \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
Explain why block A has a steady final temperature
Predict the cooling curve for block B by drawing a line on the graph in Fig. 5.2
Explain why the results for block B are slightly different from the results for block A
The results for block B are slightly different from the results for block A
Fig. 5.1 shows two metal blocks, A and B, which are the same size and made of the same material. Block A has a dull black surface and block B has a shiny white surface
The starting temperature of both blocks is \(80^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Fig. 5.2 shows the cooling curve for block A
Show the arrangement of the molecules in a solid
Draw a diagram in the box above the word 'solid' in Fig. 6.1. Draw at least **10** molecules
Show the arrangement of the molecules in a gas
Draw a diagram in the box above the word 'gas' in Fig. 6.1. Draw at least **10** molecules
State the name of the process by which a solid changes into a liquid
State the name of the process by which a gas changes into a liquid
In Fig. 6.1, the circles represent molecules. The diagram shows the arrangement of the molecules in a liquid
State the name given to the movement of the smoke particles
Fig. 6.3 shows a smoke particle as seen with the microscope
Show how the smoke particle moves by drawing a series of lines on Fig. 6.3
The temperature in the glass box decreases
Describe any changes in the movement of the smoke particles
Fig. 6.2 shows a microscope used for viewing smoke particles in a small glass box. A bright light shines into the box
The box contains smoke particles and air molecules
A student views the smoke particles through the microscope
The smoke particles are moving
Fig. 7.2 shows three of the stop-watches. The stop-watches show three of the values recorded for the time interval
Calculate the average value for the time intervals shown on the stop-watches in Fig. 7.2
average time interval =   .........  s
State the name of the instrument needed to measure the distance between the teacher and the students
The distance between the teacher and the students is \(415\mathrm{m}\)
The average time for the sound to travel between the teacher and the students is \(1.29\mathrm{s}\)
Calculate the speed of sound
speed of sound =   .........  m/s
A group of students are taking measurements so they can calculate the speed of sound
The students and their teacher are outside
The teacher holds two blocks of wood and the students have stop-watches
The teacher stands a long distance from the students, as shown in Fig. 7.1
All the students can see the teacher clearly
The teacher claps the two blocks of wood together to produce a loud sound. The students measure the time interval between seeing the teacher clap and hearing the sound
State the name for the dashed line shown in Fig. 8.1
State the letter, \(a, b, c, d, e\) or \(f,\) which indicates the angle of incidence of the ray in Fig. 8.1
State the letter, \(a, b, c, d, e\) or \(f,\) which indicates the angle of refraction of the ray in Fig. 8.1
The diagram in Fig. 8.1 shows a ray of light travelling from a glass block into air
Continue the paths of the two rays in Fig. 8.2 to show how the lens forms an image of the object
On Fig. 8.2, draw an arrow to represent the image
Tick \((\checkmark)\) two rows to indicate the nature of the image formed by the lens in Fig. 8.2
The diagram in Fig. 8.2 shows an object and a thin converging lens
Two rays are drawn from the object to the lens. The points marked F are the principal focuses of the lens
The circuit diagrams in Fig. 9.1 and Fig. 9.2 each show two resistors connected to a battery
Fig. 9.1 shows two resistors connected in series
Fig. 9.2 shows two resistors connected in parallel
All the resistors have the same resistance. Ignore the resistance of the ammeters
Fig. 9.1 Fig. 9.2
Compare the currents in the ammeters by completing the sentences
The lights in a room are connected in parallel with a power supply
State one advantage of connecting the lights in parallel
The circuit diagram in Fig. 9.3 shows a resistor Q connected to a battery
The current in resistor Q is 0.048A. The potential difference (p.d.) across resistor Q is 12V
Calculate the resistance of resistor Q. Include the unit in your answer
resistance =   .........  unit   .........

The potential difference (p.d.) across the primary coil is \(240\mathrm{V}\) a.c
Calculate the p.d. across the secondary coil

half-life of californium-241 =   .........  min

count rate =   .........  counts/s
Californium-241 is a radioactive isotope. A scientist measures the count rate from a sample of californium-241 as it decays. Table 11.2 shows the results
